description: From Italian duetto (“short musical composition for two voices”), diminutive of due (“two”).

entries.meaning: (music) A musical composition in two parts, each performed by a single voice (singer, instrument or univoce ensemble).
(music) A song composed for and/or performed by a duo.
A pair or couple, especially one that is harmonious or elegant.

verbs.description: duet (third-person singular simple present duets, present participle duetting or dueting, simple past and past participle duetted or dueted)

examples: When you can spare time from duetting, coquetting, and claretting with your Hibernians of both sexes, let me have a line from you.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, zoology, of pairs of animals) To communicate (warnings, mating calls, etc.) through song.
(transitive) To perform (sing, play, etc.) as a duet.
examples: After the Lord's Prayer the Missionaries duetted a hymn while the children stared at me.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (of two people) To say at the same time, to chorus.
examples: “My dear papa!” duetted the girls; but there was something in the husband and father's face, that told the three ladies it would be worse than useless to raise that question at present.
